column1: Will Ashraf Ghani either flee Afghanistan or cease to be its president before 1 January 2022?
column6: ['Leader Entry/Exit', 'Security and Conflict']

Wow. A very sudden collapse indeed. Quite clear that western intelligence vastly overestimated capacity of Afghan govt to hold the country, and underestimated the ease with which the Afghan people acquiesced to, or even welcomed, the Taliban.
Done
Bit of a cheat here, as he was just reported to have fled.
And there it is. Ghani reported leaving country for Tajikistan.
Ghani has fled the country.
In the fast moving news world we inhabit today...
We appear to be in the end game [1].
I believe that this is now effectively confirmed, due to de facto Taliban control of the capital. I'm not sure of the exact situation on the ground, but see no road for Ghani to remain in power.

https://english.alarabiya.net/News/world/2021/08/15/Taliban-begin-offensive-on-Kabul-Interior-Ministry “Afghanistan’s president will abdicate in the next few hours after the Taliban entered the city on Sunday, according to Al Arabiya sources.”
President Ashraf Ghani before surrendering power. Presumably will leave the country within hours. https://twitter.com/ianbremmer/status/1426871735673098244

Questions 15 and 16 linked. Western embassies have closed, are closing and evacuation plans are in play. It is reported that the US military is preparing to lower its flag over the embassy and so signalling closure. Jalalabad has been taken, cutting escape to the east and leaving Kabul vulnerable to be overrun. The unexpected folding of the government forces has exacerbated the capitulation of the country to the Taliban in days rather than weeks as suggested by the US. The Taliban have turned government helicopter pilots and using Russian helicopters - they now have an airforce (ish). Ghani will have to surrender or escape to ?

Estimated probability of Taliban control of Kabul, including relevant governing apparatus before 2022 should be ~99%. Likelihood of Taliban's desire to replace Ghani should be almost as high since he will be seen as a US puppet. More likely than not Ghani will attempt to flee because he has the means and should stand to live a better life outside Afghanistan than inside under Taliban rule. Final estimation 97%, with probability against consisting of either a Taliban capture of Ghani and desire to use him as political capital while nominally keeping his office, or an unexpected last-minute intervention by the US and or others which lasts until at least 1 / 1 / 2022 and keeps Ghani in office. These contingencies should be very unlikely, hence only 3% probability being assigned against.

He has no further instrumental or symbolic value to anybody. Looks like his choices are increasingly limited to either relatively comfortable exile at the expense of US taxpayers somewhere (Qatar is lovely this time of year) or torture and execution at the hands of either the Taliban or his loving constituents. (The expression, "I didn't have any choice" is never accurate.)

Speed, execution, and focus of the Taliban to retake the country is frightening. The US is pulling out personnel from the embassy, and news reports indicate the military and police is collapsing [https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/8/14/afghan-president-ghani-vows-to-fight-taliban-offensive]. Finally, resignation may become the only way for Ashraf Ghani to reduce bloodshed in the capital [https://www.wsj.com/articles/afghan-president-ashraf-ghani-says-he-wants-to-avoid-bloodshed-as-taliban-encircle-kabul-11628939781].

Okay. "The Taliban captured the city of Pul-e-Alam, around 70 kilometres (43 miles) from the capital, Kabul, a local provincial council member said." And I agree with the following. “It’s not about President Ghani anymore, it’s about making the transition as bloodlessly, as orderly and as swiftly as possible... if Kabul falls under pressure, all hopes for a political settlement will be lost.” https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/8/14/taliban-launch-new-assault-on-northern-afghan-city-live Mr. Ghani has come under growing pressure from Afghan politicians to resign so that a transitional government headed by someone else could negotiate a cease-fire with the Taliban and prevent the storming of Kabul, the country’s capital. https://www.wsj.com/articles/afghan-president-ashraf-ghani-says-he-wants-to-avoid-bloodshed-as-taliban-encircle-kabul-11628939781 [ Aug. 14, 2021 ]

,The Taliban is heading for Kabul at speed with the intention of declaring 'independence' or a caliphate by Thursday; https://bit.ly/37EnSCJ. One of the priorities of the Taliban is the departure of Ashraf Ghani. The Doha talks have largely been a distraction for the west and international community while the Taliban prepared for the US departure. Ghani has promised the Afghan population that the government will ensure no further displacement of the population takes place and the "...the remobilisation of our security and defense forces is our top priority, and serious steps are being taken in this regard.”
The US Embassy has begun destroying documents, always a bad sign. See https://www.cnn.com/2021/08/13/politics/afghanistan-embassy-72-scramble/index.html.
I thought things would deteriorate quickly, but the Taliban seems to not only be winning but also taking no prisoners. To me he's gone now.
The Taliban do not need him for anything, nor do any of the other players. He will be spending more time with his family. If he's lucky.

Kabul is encircled All major provincial centers taken. Ismail Khan the Lion of Herat shows up in Taliban propaganda. Not looking good for Kabul without a Berlin style airlift. Not going to happen. No air bases. @Hesch you have to adjust upwards Apropos of Stalin's comment to Churchill How many divisions does the pope have. How many divisions does Bildt or EU have? Noble sentiment
Worth adding this statement by Imran Khan (one of the most obvious and influential external power brokers in this conflict, alongside China) to our forecasts:

Ashraf Ghani is considered a warmonger by the Taliban who insist on his removal prior to any agreement. It is now debatable given their rapid success and the collapse of the Afghan government forces that any agreement will be necessary and the demise of Ghani is imminent. Questions 15 and 16 of this series are obviously linked to the same set of conditions that are now developing in Afghanistan. The relocation of US and UK armed forces to Kabul is to ensure the safety of its citizens rather than shoring up the Afghan government and its president.

Kandahar confirmed fallen in reporting. Lashkar Gar still pending confirmation but with Kandahar gone LKG is effectively cut off so will fall in short order if it hasn’t already. Highly symbolic losses that will play hell with the morale of any still loyal ANSF personnel.

Incredibly, 3 out of the 5 largest cities fell in a 24 hour period, so the odds have to go up. It seems the Taliban were more competent than people thought and had been laying a lot of the groundwork with various alliances with local leaders for this rapid offensive. The 300k-plus Afghan National Army seems to have existed mostly on paper. This has been reported previously, and the problem is perhaps worse today than it was a few years ago: https://www.military.com/daily-news/2019/08/02/afghanistan-loses-42000-troops-crackdown-ghost-soldiers.html
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/8/12/afghanistan-offer-power-sharing-taliban-official https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/8/12/afghanistan-taliban-kandahar-prison-police-ghazni-live-updates
Even with US Forces, not going to roll back all the battles lost
Kandahar, the 2nd largest city, has just fallen: https://twitter.com/Conflicts/status/1425819929995989003 It's hard to imagine Kabul is far behind.
The fall of Herat this afternoon and (with mixed reporting at this time) possibly also Lashkar Gar and Kandahar really feels like an important line of certainty now crossed.

Hope I'm wrong but the situation is evolving quickly with Kandahar close to crumbling. The deployment of US troops is more worrisome than not, since it's primary mission is to evacuate some US personell. Shadows of Saigon.
US sends 3000 US 82d Airborne to defend Kabul
Becomes more probable every minute . Kabul could fall before winter

Moving up today with Kabul confirming the offer of a power sharing deal with the Taliban. With or without Ghani's premiership being offered up as part of this deal this announcement seems to be a demonstration of just how far the Afghan government have been pushed / pulled to reach this point and how far they are apparently willing to compromise.
One possibility is to flee to another part of Afghanistan, which wouldn't count as fleeing Afghanistan.

making a big jump up due to the offer of a power sharing deal to Taliban. As of yesterday Taliban still said that Ghani was the biggest obstacle to and end to conflict so I wonder if the govts offer is for Ghani to resign? I will drop back down a bit when i hear more of this offer and result
Updating here due to the dire situation in Afghanistan and the updated timeline of when Kabul could fall (which would likely cause Pres. Ghani to flee).
Ghani will flee or be killed. Taliban have the inertia and about 3 months left to surge.

Yesterday I gave the Taliban three months before the brutal Afghan weather slowed their advance, today US and UK intelligence reports (through media connections) state the possibility (key word: possibility) that the Taliban could have Kabul surrounded in 1 month and overrun in 3.
Things have changed rapidly in just the past couple of weeks. I am changing my odds drastically here.
https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/taliban-fighters-capture-eighth-provincial-capital-six-days-2021-08-11/
Coming down a little (-8%) when accounting for the Afghan winter fighting season drop off (due to the combination of challenging weather and variable quality road and logistics routes).

For anyone who missed it UK and US government travel bulletins for Afghanistan changed on the 6th and 7th August August 21 advising all citizens to leave the country immediately by the most expedient commercial means [1] and [2].

https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/defence/afghan-president-views-peace-talks-as-dead-prepares-for-civil-war/articleshow/85191898.cms An increasingly sad state of affairs, now it comes down to what will Ghani do 1> Will he stay with the sinking ship and rally his troops and citizens till the end ( if this is the case then the timeline maybe stretched a bit) 2> Will he flee (more likely)
It's looking more likely than it was a week ago. Presumably Kabul will still be a tough nut to crack for the Taliban though and could still be longer than 4-5 months off
Could I recommend that interested parties in this question take a look at Heela Najibullah's twitter account [1].

Pace of advance over the weekend is significant, if currently localised to the border regions. Fall of Lashkar Gah and/or Herat in the next 7 - 10 days now seems significantly more likely and are events which may well signal the real beginning of the end for the current administration.

Why this could happen The fate of his predecessor will be something that he will be keen to avoid and so that might force him to flee before it is too late. I doubt whether the Taliban would repeat something like that, given that in the longer term if they wish to govern (even as a conservative nation) they will need some legitimacy in foreign media. Afghanistan still relies on the US for sizeable aid. I have very little hopes on them moderating their hardline stance on key issues and achieving any long term stability in the region even if they were to achieve some power https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohammad_Najibullah

Think its worth looking beyond the tactical 24 hour battle raging around the DCs and look above at the strategic. China's increasingly reported engagement with the Taliban leadership is an interesting longer term indicator of where the worlds power brokers think the power is going to lay.

https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/7/27/taliban-afghanistan-political-settlement-trust https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/7/23/taliban-afghanistan-ashraf-ghani-civil-war https://www.cbsnews.com/news/afghanistan-ashraf-ghani-blames-us-troop-pullout-for-worsening-violence-taliban-gains/

So AP report s 9 out of the. 10 districts of LG occupied.. The Afghan army and commandos are fight ing hard to defend tenth they have Big airstrikes coming. Based on continued air support for 2 months .minus 10 Looks like His 1968 not Danang 1975

Day 3 Taliban post Eid offensive. Fighting continues in Lashgar Gah a very small center 16 square blocks. BBC report seems the best summary. Reports of US airstrikes late Monday Taliban attacked from two fronts. Seized radio/ tv station. Fighting continues in outlying Kandahar and Herat. Issue still in doubt. Longer fighting and battles favor regime. Even though Taliban is puppet for Pakistani Army Intelligence, taking Kandahar, Herat, and Lashgar has not overwhelmed Afghan army and fighting continues.
A 6 month security plan was tabled in Parliament with support from both houses. This is not the panicking rulings of someone about to flee.

The Taliban is pretty clearly winning, and I don't expect they will be in much of a mood to leave the current power structure in place. There's always a chance of intervention by a regional power (Turkey seems most likely) but as of now it's looking like Kabul is likely to fall.
Not looking great for Ghani or his country. At least he's survived two weeks since I put 16% in. Bumped it to 20% for now.

-6 "Depend on it, sir, when a man knows he is to be hanged in a fortnight,it concentrates his mind wonderfully". Samuel Johnson. There is going to be a long civil war. As suggested by Former Pak ambassador to US Haqquani, the prospect of Taliban rule has United the Afghan people to resist.www.bbc.com Haqquani observed that among other things, the Taliban were advancing like a regular army strongly suggesting that Pak military train supply control and perhaps command the Taliban forces. That US under Trump negotiated with the adversary not the ally and the Doha agreement accordingly failed. Finally Haqquani noted that the failure to train and supply maintain Aghan air force after NATO withdrawal coupled with the withdrawal of contractors, neutralized any air advantage.

Movement on the three major cities this quickly (even if not yet successfully) escalates the timeframe in which Ghani's presidency will be forced into the hazard (if it isn't already there). Kandahar's fall in particular may signal the last moments for the current Afghan government.
Heavy fighting in Herat, Lashkar Gah and Kandahar. Taliban have seized strategic road between Herat City and it's airport. American airstrikes reported in all 3 battles. Plus 5
Taliban will take care of him

Anyone who reads the Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction report has to be concerned about the survival of the current government. This forecast plus 5 is to be re evaluated as frequently as possible.

Difficult to find a base rate for this one. Most helpful precedents are probably Vietnam and Soviets in Afghanistan. In each case the incumbent government supported by the outgoing party lasted significantly longer than the 5 month timeline provided here. So I think the have to start with the view that is is unlikely - somewhere around the 15% mark. You then have the fact that the US is still providing air support (and looks likely to continue to do so), and that the Taliban's gains so far have been predominantly limited to the countryside. It also gets very cold in Kabul over winter, so if we presume that (a) the Taliban will likely need to take the capital in order for the government to fall and (b) it will be harder to take over winter, then the timeframe for action really is tight. None of these factors on their own make it impossible, but I think together they reduce the probability to around the 5% figure.

Taliban seem to be playing for time in Qatar [1], indicating that they may just be waiting out the US before closing in on the district centres and then the capital. US intervention seems unlikely whilst they are so absorbed with their own internal strifes and public mood is very much with leaving the Afghans to their fate.
US has been providing close air support outside Kandahar. That was one condition of my original forecast. I remain at 5 Percent.
Increase a tad because one of the Taliban bottom lines for peace talks is that Ghani leaves office https://aje.io/4mgtam
Mollifying a little (-5%) given that any major push will likely occur after the final 31 August withdraw date has passed, leaving little time for this question to resolve.

85% of Afghanistan is already under Taliban control [1] Not all of this is captured in the last few weeks though. The fight is on palace doorsteps already so the question isn't if but when he flees or ceases to be the president. Given that there is 5 and half months and the speed of taliban forces development my initial prior would be about 75%.
volatile situation. taliban are active. short time frame through. https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-57714808 https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-57770436

Looking at the regions that the Taliban control, similarities can be drawn to the Tet Offensive during the Vietnam war. While Taliban forces are doing well in the countryside - where they have been fighting for their existence against foreign forces for the last decades, their skills will (I feel) be far less effective in the cities. This implies that a more long term strategy may have to be adapted in order to remove Ashraf Ghani from power, that may provide him past the deadline.

The Taliban may not be taking over as fast as I thought. A leading US General said today that the roughly half of the districts that the Taliban have now taken over were lost over the past 6 to 10 months. https://aje.io/pzb248 This comment was in a video clip on AJ news rather than this article though. It will be interesting to see if the fighting scales up again after Eid holidays
The Taliban are on the move.

There has been a persistent problem with Afghan police & military forces holding positions w/o western support. The Taliban already controls most of the land and one might argue that Ghani is already not president for much of the country. The challenge is to understand what it means if Ghani olds the title and the government only holds 1-3 cities.

The situation in Afghanistan is moving the Taliban's way at a very fast pace. They clearly seem to be heading towards taking control of the entire country. Forcing out Ghani could make this go even faster with fewer lives lost. This might appeal to Ghani and accelerate his departure. On the other hand, most people in power do hate to leave.

The resignation of President Ghani to make way for an interim government has been a key demand of the Taliban (Al Jazeera, Pajhwok), and this is likely to remain the cornerstone of an expected peace deal proposal by the Taliban in the coming weeks (Al Jazeera), indicated also by attacks against the presidential palace in the last days (CNN). Ghani has reportedly also come under increasing criticism from political parties, on the backdrop of the disputed result of the May 2019 elections. Also his relation with Pakistan which is (again) becoming an key actor in inter-Afghan peace process has soured (Dawn). If President Ghani continues to object to resign, the Taliban are likely to further exploit these fractures in the Afghan government and political elites in Kabul, further increasing the pressure on Ghani. As a result, Ghani departure is likely, however may drag on beyond 1 January 2022.
https://twitter.com/i/status/1417397544196399127
As the US pulls out of Afghanistan the likelihood of him leaving Afghanistan is very likely
Taliban getting into the cities is going to be really challenging. They'll easily overrun outside the high density areas. Ghani won't flee, but i think there's about a 50% chance of an assassination.

https://mobile.twitter.com/TOLOnews/status/1416965746299658241 https://twitter.com/1TVNewsAF/status/1417057103894695936 A couple more data points there. It seems when some Taliban guerillas come out of hiding to take some far-flung district without much fighting, it makes international news, but when Afghan government forces move in to retake it, there's barely any follow-up reporting. The more I look at the reported facts on the ground, the more of a mistake I think I made to place this at 90% initially.
Base Rate: 25%

Taliban control mostly rural/low population areas. Kabul will be a much more difficult territory to control. Likely Taliban will strike areas in Kabul when able, but controlling enough to force Ghani to step down or flee the country seems unlikely. Likelihood of assassination or illness might even be higher.

Kabul is likely to be the last domino to fall. Still some US presence if only to protect their embassy, and less local support for Taliban. Agree with the comments that this is more likely to be 12-24 months rather than next 6 months. Possibility that Ghani is assassinated or dies of illness in remainder 2021 cannot be discounted.

Taliban advances will be slowed in densly populated areas as the people living there have more freedoms to loose than in rural areas and therefore are more likely to resist more fiercly. I therefore think, while it is very likely (0.8) to happen within the next 3 years, not in this questions timeframe.
https://www.tagesschau.de/ausland/asien/afghanistan-gefechte-101.html

Given the other sponsors of post US war, the Turks, Chinese, Pakistanis, have opposing strategies in Afghanistan, he is not in the first vote for all to agree. They have their leadibg candidates that work for their country but not all of them. Militarily, it is the Ukranian cemetery of the area. He has neither the sponsorship or incoming personal revenue, and his history as leader, to want to hang around there.

Afghani presidents don't seem to cease to be president very often. Rabbani coninued to be president even in exile so can discount that. He is 72 and seems spritely so should have a good 6 months left in him. No political challange likely as has a deal with his nearest rival who will be the chief taliban peace negotiator.

According to NYT intelligence assessment is Ghani govt could fall in 6 months to 2 years. I assume that Ghani who was last seen in Tashkent Excoriating Imre Khan for Pak support of Taliban. Meanwhile Abdullah returns to unproductive peace talks with Taliban in Doha

Sure, Reasons: China&Pakistan sees opporrunities in New (Stabilized neighboring country even if it is dominated by Taliban). -Taliban going to use mine sources as any normal government (Sohail Shaheen,Taliban speaker said, this means investment opportunities to china in Afganistan afrer US gone).

Ghani did not start out oversupplied with friends and allies, and one gathers is not regarded as indispensable by anyone in a position to dispense with him. There is ample precedent for the US flying its puppets to safety once they have ceased to be even marginally useful; the only actual question is, I think, whether this eventuality will occur before this deadline. Seems to be no solid reason to think otherwise. He might make it to Michaelmas, but he will be dead or gone or both by Boxing Day.

My perception about militias is correct. See www.nytimes.com and pictures of Gen Dostom militia and ANA digging trenches in front of Mazar a Sharif.Article also States pace of fighting has slowed. Article also depicts Hazarra and Uzbek militia's defending areas of Balkh province. Excellent article. "Right now we have a common enemy' Attta Muhammad Noor

Taliban are declaring they have control of 85% of the country with Afghan security personnel escaping across the Iran and Tajikistan borders. There is not a lot of confidence being shown in the Afghan army to defend the country and the air support required by the armed forces and depended upon by the outgoing US administration will be lost due to the withdrawal of US soldiers and contractors and the resultant loss in maintenance of aircraft. The Taliban control strategic areas along borders with central Asian states including key trade routes. Ashraf Ghani has lost the foreign troops protecting his position. His armed forces would appear to be ineffective or inadequate or not willing and the Taliban are confident in obtaining power by force. His only hope could lie with China that would like to use Afghanistan’s strategic location as a trade hub with links to the Middle East, Central Asia and Europe. The Chinese maybe wary given that Afghanistan has never been colonized, resisted all foreign invaders such as the British, Russia and the US. The trade hub would depend on peace and stability, two issues not known in Afghanistan and history shows that foreign intervention for those power’s advantages have been repelled without any regard for trade or economics. I will suggest that Ashraf Ghani’s tenure as President is not secure and has few allies who want to enmesh themselves in another conflict with the tribes of Afghanistan. Only the timing of his departure is in question. https://edition.cnn.com/2021/07/13/asia/afghanistan-taliban-commandos-killed-intl-hnk/index.html https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/militia-commanders-rush-aid-afghan-forces-against-taliban-2021-07-09/
The Afghan president doesn't have many allies inside or outside of Afghanistan. => I believe his collapse is inevitable.

Upon doing a lot more research, I am dropping my odds of this happening this quickly. Not that I don't think the Taliban will eventually take Kabul and win the war, but the gains thusfar have been mostly in rural areas, and the Afghan National Army remains large and well-equipped, with the Taliban continuing to avoid large, direct confrontations.

If we assume that Pres. Ghani will stay in power (not flee or cease to be president) as long as Kabul is held, then we can use the government's hold of Kabul as a basis for a prediction. According to reporting the Taliban isn't ready to advance on the capital which would possibly bring in more American engagement via airstrikes (https://www.cnn.com/2021/07/16/politics/us-intel-kabul-taliban/index.html).

Aggressive timeline but definitely seems highly likely. Just looking at the map of Taliban control, they are making gains practically every day, with Kabul soon to be surrounded and cut off even more than it has been already: https://www.longwarjournal.org/mapping-taliban-control-in-afghanistan News reports are of Afghan soldiers surrendering basically as fast as they can or just abandoning their weapons and melting away
Initial forecast. Those who ignore history do so at their (and others') peril.

Unlikely to be rout. A melee. We better support private militias in provinces and provide close in air support to govt. Forces around Kabul or a rout by 9 30 2021. Post Russian intervention aftermath portends 2 to 3 year civil war. Without close air support Kabul and waging asymmetrical warfare with US supported militias on all borders other than Pakistan rout poss by October 1. At this point Abdullah Abdullah may be better bet. 10 to 20 percent chance cease fire talks cease Abdullah takes over. At best we can hope for long stalemate Closing Bagram dumb Better send Warthogs and train Afghan pilots and expand intelligence assets covert. Send message to Iran PRC and Pak and world, No rout will occur most likely but national government a failure
